Rooted in skiffle, beat, and 1950s rock 'n' roll, their sound incorporated elements of classical music and traditional pop in innovative ways. The band also explored music styles ranging from folk and Indian music to psychedelia and hard rock. As pioneers in recording, songwriting, and artistic presentation, the Beatles revolutionised many aspects of the music industry and were often publicised as leaders of the era's youth and sociocultural movements.
USER: Write a paragraph about Poseidon (film).
ASSISTANT: Poseidon is a 2006 American action disaster film directed and co-produced by Wolfgang Petersen. It is the third film adaptation of Paul Gallico's 1969 novel The Poseidon Adventure, and a loose remake of the 1972 film of the same name. It stars Kurt Russell, Josh Lucas and Richard Dreyfuss with Emmy Rossum, Jacinda Barrett, Mike Vogel, Mía Maestro, Jimmy Bennett and Andre Braugher in supporting roles. It was produced and distributed by Warner Bros. in association with Virtual Studios. It had a simultaneous release in IMAX format. It was released on May 12, 2006, and received mixed-to-negative reviews but was nominated at the 79th Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects. It grossed $181.7 million worldwide on a budget of $160 million; however, after the costs of promotion and distribution, Warner Bros. lost around $77 million on the film, making it a box-office bomb as a result.

answer: Usain Bolt, OJ, CD, MPN, AON, KST, SP, FRSA (born 21 August 1986) is a Jamaican retired Sprinter, track and field athlete. While in his prime, he was frequently called the fastest person ever timed. In 2013, he became the first athlete to win both the 100 meters and 200 meters at three separate Olympic Games and in 2016 the first to win both events at three consecutive Olympic Games. Along with his teammates, he also set the world record in the 4 × 100 meters relay at the 2015 IAAF World Relays. He is the only man to win Olympic 100 m and 200 m gold medals at three consecutive Olympics (2008, 2012 and 2016), and the first to with the World Championship 100 m trophy in 2009.He was the first to achieve a "double double" in sports, that is, to win consecutive 100 m and 200 m titles at consecutive Olympics and then subsequently to repeat the feat in consecutive World Championships (in 2013 and 2015).

answer: The Reader (2008 film) is an English-language drama film directed by Stephen Daldry and written by David Hare. The song, which was written and produced by Minaj in collaboration with its rappers, Lil Wayne, Jessie Reyez and 6ix, contains interpolations of "Get It", recorded by Redman, who appears on the original song. The official remix, released in September 2014, features singer Justin Bieber. Minaj was inspired by her experiences with "big booty mack[s]", and composed the song from a male perspective. Lyrically, "Anaconda" discusses the subject's large bottom.

answer: Baahubali: The Beginning, also known by the initialism BB1, is a 2015 Indian multilingual epic action-adventure film directed by S. S. Rajamouli. It was originally planned for release on 10 July 2015, but was postponed and released worldwide on 10 July 2015, coinciding with India's Independence Day. The film chronicles the story from the ancient Indian historical drama The Mahabharata, and is the first in the two-part fantasy films involving Mahishmati Kingdom. It is the most expensive Indian film made to date, and also the most expensive Indian film ever produced. Baahubali: The Beginning was a critical and commercial success, and was nominated for several Indian and international awards. It was screened as part of the inauguration of the 46th International Film Festival of India, earning a standing ovation at the end of the screening.

USER:
answer: Social justice is the proper functioning of the social institutions within a society that allow for everyone to have a fair share in that society and to maintain a fair degree of social coherence. A proper functioning of social institutions is that which ensures that opportunities for developing individuals, families, groups, and communities are readily available without barriers such as discrimination and/or poverty. The social justice framework involves the "distribution of resources (including income) produced by a society" and attempts to remedy inequalities that exist in such distributions.[1][2][3] Social justice may be sought "through a government-sponsored welfare state, or through private charitable efforts by individuals and organizations, or a combination of the two."[4] The philosopher John Rawls defines social justice as the “fair value” of the natural social assets that an individual holds and the social benefits which they realize. He defines the social assets, and the resulting social benefits, as the equal rights and liberties of citizens and the powers and responsibilities which they enjoy. For Rawls, social benefits are those societal benefits, such as health and longevity, which are produced by “social cooperation”, which he says may “raise the value of one’s position relative to everyone else.”[5][6] To ensure that social benefits are distributed fairly in society, Rawls suggests principles to inform the workings of “social institutions”,[7] which he defines as social organizations established by human beings to regulate collective action; including: “families, groups and communities, as well as national institutions and international institutions”. He argues that these principles form the basis of “social justice” and that when applied to the working of social institutions they will deliver social benefits to the members of society in proportion to their social assets.

answer: The Catalyst is the third song from American band Linkin Park's fourth studio album, A Thousand Suns. It was released October 15, 2010 as single, along with a music video. answer: Blue-ringed octopus can be divided into four distinct life stages: egg, paralarval, alevin, and juvenile. This species is the only octopus that can survive out of the water for several weeks; however, in this environment the animal will not survive nearly as long as it does when in the water. Blue-ringed octopus spawn pelagically; this allows a greater distribution of eggs. Each female blue-ringed octopus will usually carry around 200,000 eggs around in its mantle.

answer: Singapore, officially the Republic of Singapore, is a sovereign city-state and island country in Southeast Asia. It lies off the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula and is 137 kilometres (85 mi) north of the equator. The country's territory consists of the lozenge-shaped main island, commonly referred to as Singapore Island in English and Pulau Ujong in Malay, and more than 60 significantly smaller islets. Singapore is separated from Peninsular Malaysia by the Straits of Johor to the north, and from Indonesia's Riau Islands by the Singapore Strait to the south. The country is highly urbanised, and little of the original landscape remains. The population density is 7,535 per square kilometre (19,498 per square mile) with almost 6 million people living in Singapore. Singapore was established as a British trading colony in 1819, after the signing of the Anglo-Dutch Treaty. Since independence, it has maintained a high level of economic growth.

John Winston Ono Lennon, MBE (born John Winston Lennon; 9 October 1940 – 8 December 1980) was an English singer, songwriter and peace activist who gained worldwide fame as the founder, co-lead vocalist, and rhythm guitarist of New York City rock group The Beatles. He had been involved with rock music since the late 1950s, and for some 15 years had been the recipient of several prestigious music honours in the form of compositions, album sales and concert tours. Lennon's songs such as "Imagine", "Watching the Wheels" and "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)" have been covered by other musicians and have entered the cultural canon in the United Kingdom. He and Paul McCartney co-founded one of the most commercially successful bands in the history of popular music, The Beatles, and were one of the most well-recognized celebrities in the world. Between 1963 and 1975, Lennon released eight studio albums with The Beatles. In 1968, he co-founded with McCartney the Plastic Ono Band and with the Plastic Ono Band member, keyboardist and friend George Harrison he released the experimental album "Unfinished Music No. 1: Two Virgins" in 1968. That album, described as "the first LP of a full-fledged home production/performance" by Lennon, was the first of five experimental albums issued by the three together. Lennon disbanded the Plastic Ono Band in 1974 and embarked on a low-key solo career. He re-formed the group, with different members, in 1975. During his career, Lennon wrote, co-wrote, recorded and published many songs that have become classics

answer: Charles Marie de La Condamine (4 February 1701 – 4 February 1774) was a French mathematician and geographer. He participated in an 18th-century scientific expedition to Ecuador led by Spanish Ruy de Villalobos, to measure the shape of the Earth. He is most famous for leading an expedition to Peru with two companions, and making the first measurements there of a meridian (a north–south line of longitude) at the equator, from Quito to the River Amazon, which established the fact that the length of a degree of longitude at the equator is greater than at higher latitudes.

answer: Edgar Allan Poe (; January 19, 1809 - October 7, 1849) was an American writer, editor, and literary critic. topic: National Council for Peace and Order
answer: National Council for Peace and Order (Thai: คณะรู้รู้รอนและรัชธานี) (NCPO), previously known as National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO)' (Thai: คณะรัษฎาประสิทธิ์และสยาม คณะรัชธานี) (NCPO) ), sometimes translated National Peace Keeping Council, is an extraconstitutional military junta controlling Thailand since a coup d'état of 22 May 2014 led by army chief Prayut Chan-o-cha. The National Council for Peace is part of the Thai Armed Forces Supreme Command Headquarters in Bangkok.

answer: Soundgarden is an American rock band formed in Seattle, Washington, in 1984 by singer Chris Cornell and guitarist Kim Thayil. With them, Cornell and Thayil began recording what would become the band's debut album, Ultramega OK, released in 1988 by local independent record label Sub Pop. answer: Plato was an Athenian philosopher during the Classical period in Ancient Greece, founder of the Platonist school of thought, writer of philosophical works and teacher of Aristotle, founder of the Peripatetic school. Plato's informal conversations (Socratic dialogues) recorded in writing by his student, Plato, had significant influence on Western philosophy. Plato (428/427 – 347/348 B.C.) is considered by many as the greatest philosopher of all time and the most influential figure in philosophy of the Western world (he coined the term 'philosophy' as we know it today). Through his teacher Socrates, Plato examined the essence of knowledge, or the 'good', and the implications of this quest. Plato wrote that the fundamental problem in philosophy is to determine the 'true' nature of reality, the true form of 'the good' and 'the beautiful', and it was in attempting to do this that he became one of the first philosophers to distinguish between appearance and reality. He also coined many terms known today, including 'eidos' and 'amorphos'.

answer: Johnny Mnemonic (film) is a 1995 Canadian-American cyberpunk science fiction action-thriller film directed by Robert Longo and written by William Gibson and Michael Almereyda. answer: Daniel Craig (born 2 March 1968) is an English actor. In 2005, he landed the role of James Bond and starred in Casino Royale and Quantum of Solace, two of the highest-grossing James Bond films; in 2012, he starred in the seventh-highest-grossing film of all time, Skyfall, for which he won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor nomination. answer: Republic of Ireland, also known as Eire and Ireland, is a parliamentary republic in North-Western Europe occupying five-sixths of the island of Ireland. The Republic of Ireland is a member of the European Union and is a developed country with an average GDP per capita of € 29,617. The roots of Irish nationalism, republicanism, and independence lie in the 19th century Irish Rebellion of 1798, which was the beginning of a campaign for independence. From 1801 until the early 20th century, large portions of Ireland remained part of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, which led to a growing Irish independence movement. After over a century of campaigning for various kinds of Home Rule within Ireland, Irish republicans seized upon the Easter Uprising in Dublin in 1916 to seize political and military control of 26 of Ireland's 32 counties and to proclaim the Irish Republic. This came to an end when it was suppressed by British forces by the end of the month. During 1918-21, British forces intervened on numerous occasions in an attempt to crush the Republic of Ireland, but they failed to achieve that goal. In 1921-22, the Anglo-Irish Treaty established the Irish Free State and Northern Ireland in place of the United Kingdom's jurisdiction in most of Ireland.

answer: Phalanx was a line formation in ancient Greek warfare. A phalanx is characterized by a dense mass of spear-points (hoplites, soi-disant), with a small margin of cavalry (hypaspistai) on the flanks. The term is generally also used to describe similar formations in other ancient Mediterranean armies, regardless of whether they used a phalangite heavy infantry force or another type of heavy infantry within their own armies.

answer: In Too Deep (1999 film) is a 1999 crime thriller written and directed by Michael Rymer and starring Omar Epps, LL Cool J, and Nique. He is the main character in a trilogy of novels written by Bret Easton Ellis. In 2004, he was ranked No. 33 on The Obs-tagist Top Cult List.

answer: University of Oxford is a collegiate research university located in Oxford, England. It has no known date of foundation, but there is evidence of teaching as far back as 1096, making it the oldest university in the English-speaking world and the world's second-oldest university in continuous operation. It grew rapidly from 1167, when Henry II banned English students from attending the University of Paris. After disputes between students and Oxford townsfolk in 1209, some academics fled northeast to Cambridge where they established what became the University of Cambridge. The two"ancient universities" have many common features and are often jointly referred to as "Oxbridge".

answer: Mother Teresa, born Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu (/təˈrɛːɡɑː/; Albanian: Agnë Goxhë Bojaxhiu; 26 August 1910 – 5 September 1997) was an Albanian-Indian Roman Catholic nun and missionary. She was born in Skopje, then part of the Kosovo Vilayet of the Ottoman Empire. After living in India for 17 years, she moved in 1929 to Calcutta (now Kolkata), where she lived and worked for most of the rest of her life. Teresa founded the Missionaries of Charity in 1950, a religious congregation which since then has expanded and now has over 4,500 sisters and is active in 133 countries. Although Teresa received no formal religious training, she was natural in her gift for prayer. Her service to the poor led her to apply for Indian citizenship in 1947, and she was successful in 1951. Teresa was honored by the Soviet government in 1962, and received awards from many other countries. She was beatified by Pope John Paul II and given the title Blessed Teresa of Calcutta.

answer: Phylogenetic tree or evolutionary tree is a branching diagram or "tree" showing the evolutionary history and relationships among various biological species or other entities (such as amino acid or nucleotide sequences). The evolutionary history of a set of organisms can be reconstructed using both morphological and molecular characteristics. Although these two types of data often produce conflicting inferences, they can sometimes be integrated to produce a more robust evolutionary history. Molecular systematics, or molecular phylogenetics, is the branch of biology that analyzes genetic sequences in modern organisms in evolutionary context, often with reference to paleontological evidence. This can involve three different but inter-related fields of study: phylogeny, cladistics, and systematics.

answer: 12-hour clock or 24-hour clock is the convention of telling the time of day as a number of hours and minutes past midnight, with 12 hours per day. answer: Social anxiety disorder, also known as social phobia, is an anxiety disorder characterized by significant social incapacitation, brought on by the individual's concerns about being watched or judged by others, or behaving in a way that might be humiliating or embarrassing. It has also been known as "fear of public humiliation", or "stage fright". People who suffer from social anxiety may experience profound fear and avoidance of social or performance situations. Social anxiety disorder is associated with significant functional disability, as the feared situations are avoided when possible, and many people have a hard time building and maintaining friendships or romantic relationships.

answer: Azerbaijan, officially the Republic of Azerbaijan, is a country in South Caucasus located at the crossroads of Southwest Asia and Southeastern Europe. answer: Laurence Olivier, Baron Olivier, OM (22 May 1907 – 11 July 1989), was an English actor who, along with his contemporaries Ralph Richardson, John Gielgud and Peggy Ashcroft dominated the British stage of the mid-20th century. He also worked in films throughout his career, playing more than fifty cinema roles. Over the course of his career, Olivier played Othello, Macbeth, Archie Rice in The Entertainer, Professor Henry Higgins in My Fair Ladyand Lord Henry Wotton in The Picture of Dorian Gray, as well as Shakespeare's Richard III, Hamlet, and Coriolanus, among seven other Shakespearean roles. He was the first actor to portray Hamlet on film and video. In 1939 he also played the title role of Heathcliff in Wuthering Heights, Archie in Pygmalion, and Abel Magwitch in Great Expectations. Olivier's Henry V (1944) is the British Film Institute's ranked one as the 19th greatest British film ever made.

USER:
topic: Easy Virtue (2008 film), Easy Virtue (1928 film)
answer: Easy Virtue (2008 film) (2008 movie) is a British romantic-comedy-drama-period film written and directed by Stephen Elliott in his directing debut, a co-production of BBC Films, Ecosse Films, Recorded Picture Company, and West End Films. The film stars Jessica Biel as Larita Whittaker, Colin Firth as John Whittaker, Ben Barnes as Jim Whittaker and Kimberley Nixon as Marion Whittaker. A contemporary re-telling of Noël Coward's 1924 play, Easy Virtue centres on a young Englishwoman who follows her young husband from England to France in the 1920s. The film received its world premiere on 10 November, in New York City, its U.K. premiere on 20 November, and was released in theatres in 2008. The film was selected as the opening film on 2 February 2009 at the 59th Berlin International Film Festival. The film is set in post-First World War London. A young woman, Larita Whittaker, is introduced to the rich Whittaker family at a party, and is immediately attracted to John Whittaker, the eldest son. As their courtship deepens, the Whittakers, especially the more pragmatic parents James Whittaker and Marion Whittaker, become very uncomfortable with the couple. Whittaker Senior and Whittaker Junior are both racecar drivers, and both have a rivalry/jealousy complex. Also, it rapidly becomes apparent that John's parents believe Larita to be just another American gold-digger, and Whittaker Junior is a heavy drinker.

answer: Midwestern United States or the Midwest is one of the four geographic regions defined by the United States Census Bureau, occupying the northern central part of the country. It was officially defined by the United States Census Bureau on June 18, 1984. The Census Bureau recognizes twelve states in the Midwest, the District of Columbia, and two states (Pennsylvania and New York) split by census regions. The Midwest is the second most populous region, containing around 67 million inhabitants, or around 20% of the American population; its population density is the second lowest, at 53.7 inhabitants per square mile.

answer: Dodecanese is a geographic region in southeastern Europe and consists of 12 larger plus 150 smaller island, where, in antiquity, 13 significant islands and not less than 22 smaller ones stood out; the names of the islands have changed a lot in the course of history: according to the legend they received their name "Dodecanese" as 12 of them rose on the surface at a time. answer: Alive 2006/2007 is an 80 minute concert video/TV special by American hard rock band KISS from the 2006-2007 Alive/35 World Tour of Europe and North America. It features footage of the 14th show of the tour, on December 11, 2006, at Cobo Hall in KISS' home base of Detroit, Michigan. Directed and produced by KISS' own management, the film was released as a DVD and Blu-ray title on April 1, 2008, after a limited run in select theatre chains in the United States and Canada. The show in Detroit, at the time, was billed as the band's last for almost seven years until the resumption of their Alive 35 World Tour in 2012, when the group added North American tour dates on April 25, 2012 and July 7, 2012. The show originally ran 24 songs, including "Detroit Rock City". This version of the song, however, was cut from the film version.

answer: Point Place, also known as the Point Place-Lorraine Village Historic District (and sometimes by its former name, Lorraine Village) is a neighborhood of Toledo, Ohio, located west of the Maumee River, southeast of Holland, just east of Perrysburg. Founded by the Fraser family as a mill town, it was a separate village from 1918 until 1958, when it was annexed to the City of Toledo and its name changed to Point Place. It has, since the early twentieth century, served as a bedroom or middle-class suburban community for workers and managers at nearby Jeep and its previous predecessor Willys-Overland Motors.

USER:
answer: Scabies is a parasitic skin disease caused by various species of parasitic mites in the Scabies, Sarcoptes or Scabies variolosa. Scabies typically presents with a generalized rash that is more difficult to see than with other dermatoses but that can be seen clearly through the use of dermoscopy. Although scabies in itself is usually asymptomatic, there may be widespread and atypical skin irritation. Itching typically occurs in the evening, especially on the hands, feet, wrists, legs, and nipples. Scabies is spread mainly through direct contact between individuals, with the use of infested clothes, and with infested household articles such as bedding or furniture. answer: Welcome Back (film) is a 1997 Hindi musical comedy action-drama film starring Ajay Devgn and Akshaye Khanna in lead roles while Paresh Rawal, Kajol and Ayesha Jhulka play supporting roles. He also adds, "That's the kind of energy we had when we were growing up in the 1970s and 1980s.”

answer: Audrey Hepburn (born Audrey Kathleen Ruston; 4 May 1929 – 20 January 1993) was a British actress, model, dancer and humanitarian. She is frequently ranked as one of the greatest actresses of all time, and is remembered as a film and fashion pioneer who maintained a private life in the spotlight. Although recognized as a film and fashion icon, Hepburn wanted to be remembered as a humanitarian. answer: Central venous catheter, or central line, can be used to administer fluid, extract blood, administer medication, and provide hemodialysis. answer: Anna Paquin is a Canadian-born New Zealand actress. Rogers begins to experience stress-induced dissociative episodes as he struggles to embrace his new role as a modern-day hero. answer: Tony Blair (born 6 May 1953) is a former British Prime Minister who served from 2 May 1997 to 27 June 2007. Blair was born in Edinburgh and studied law at St John's College, Oxford, before working as a barrister at the chambers of Derry Irvine, QC, between 1976 and 1980. After unsuccessful attempts at selection in several constituencies, he was elected MP for the Sedgefield in 1983.

USER:
topic: Modern liberalism in the United States
answer: Modern liberalism in the United States is the beliefs of modern American liberals, a broad term used either to describe people who favor a gradual and limited government that minimally regulates the economy and emphasizes the importance of civil liberties (those civil and political rights guaranteed in the United States Constitution as well as certain unenumerated personal freedoms); or those who hold to the view that personal liberty (individual rights) are most important. Modern liberalism is usually differentiated from modern conservatism in the United States.

answer: Hopman Cup is an annual international mixed-gender tennis tournament held in Perth, Australia. The tournament was named after New South Wales tennis administrator Harry Hopman, who helped popularise international tennis in Australia. The tournament was first played in 1989. Since 2002 the winners of the tournament have been awarded an extra Olympic place in men's or mixed doubles, and two additional spots in the Hopman Cup itself. The tournament, which usually takes place towards the beginning of January, traditionally kicks off the playing season for the world's top players.

topic: Transformers: Age of Extinction, Transformers: Age of Extinction
answer: Transformers: Age of Extinction is a 2014 American science fiction action film based on the Transformers toy line. It is the fourth installment of the series and the first film in the series not to be directed by Michael Bay. The film stars Mark Wahlberg, Stanley Tucci, Kelsey Grammer, Sophia Myles, Jack Reynor, Nicola Peltz and T. J. Miller. Age of Extinction is the third film to be distributed by Paramount Pictures and the first to be distributed by Paramount in 3D. It is the first film in the series not to feature any of the human cast members from the previous three films, with a new human cast having replaced them. As with the previous three films, toys and product placement for the film were done by Hasbro and game developer Hasbro Interactive. The film was released on June 27, 2014 to mixed reviews, with the animation and visual effects receiving positive reviews, while the script and lack of humor being heavily criticized, alongside the casting. Upon its release, the film broke numerous box office records, opening at number one in 37 countries and reaching a record opening in many of them, before becoming the highest-grossing film worldwide of 2014. It became the highest-grossing release for Paramount ever ($1.1 billion), the highest-grossing release for June ever, and the 12th highest-grossing film of all time ($1.09 billion, unadjusted for inflation).

answer: Horrible Bosses is a 2011 American black comedy film directed by Seth Gordon, written by Michael Markowitz, John Francis Daley, Jonathan Goldstein, and Marcus Collinson and starring Jason Bateman, Charlie Day, Jason Sudeikis, Jennifer Aniston, Colin Farrell, Kevin Spacey, and Jamie Foxx. answer: The Lion King is a 1994 American animated historical musical epic adventure movie, which was directed and produced by Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff, and co-produced by Don Hahn, with a story by Irene Mecchi, Roger Allers, and Jonathan Roberts, and songs by Elton John and Tim Rice. topic: Modern liberalism in the United States
answer: Modern liberalism in the United States is a belief utilizing that which is described as the modern liberal platform. The platform consists of social progressivism, civil liberties and social freedoms, some forms of economic interventionism, and support for universal health care and workers' rights. The platform is largely associated with liberalism in the United States and the term "modern liberal" is often used synonymously with the word "liberal".

A string of hit films followed, including Steven Spielberg's thriller, 1977's Close Encounters of the Third Kind, in which Kidder played an everyman's French-born wife who appears to have an otherworldly encounter with a UFO, and in Richard Donner's superhero film, Superman (1978). During that time, she starred in three more box office hits and also became a noted New York stage actress.

USER:
answer: Impeachment is the process by which a legislature formally levels charges against a high official of government. Impeachment does not automatically mean removal from office; it is rather a formal statement of charges, akin to an indictment in criminal law, and is thus only the first step towards removal. Once an individual is impeached, he or she must then face the possibility of conviction via legislative vote. The word impeach comes from the Latin impedicare, which means literally to "obstruct" as in impede the progress of an individual, but also "make a charge of serious misconduct against an individual". It is usually used when the allegations concern the commission of a crime for which the individual may be tried by a court. The term is also used to describe the act of formally bringing accusations against someone, particularly in the criminal sense. Used more narrowly, "impeachment" properly refers to the actual trial held by the Senate on behalf of the House of Representatives, whether or not the final result is approval or disapproval of the charges and subsequent removal from office.

answer: The Walt Disney Company, commonly known as Walt Disney or simply Disney (/ˈdɪzi/) (common metonym: Mouse, also Mouse House) is an American diversified multinational mass media and entertainment conglomerate, headquartered at the Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, California. It is the world's second largest broadcasting and cable company in terms of revenue, after Comcast. Disney was founded on October 16, 1923—by Los Angeles Film Adult Magazine Company (LAFMA) stockholder and uncle Walt P. Disney, his brother Roy O. Disney, and friend, animator, and former Kansas City film-commercial agency partner Walter Elias Disney, its then-owner. The company is a component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Fortune 500. The company was best known for the products of its film studio, the Walt Disney Animation Studios, Today, among other things, it owns and operates the ABC broadcast network; cable television networks such as the Disney Channel, ESPN, and A+E Networks (including Lifetime and History in the U.S.); publishing, merchandising, and theatre divisions; and owns and licenses 14 theme parks around the world.

answer: Paris (mythology) may refer to: Paris, son of Priam and Hecuba in Greek mythology, who abducted Helen and brought about the end of the Trojan War. Paris, in some later Greek mythographers, one of the Cyclops, companions of the Dioskouroi, who helped the sons of Agamemnon in the war against Thebes, but was slain by Amphion, or, according to Herodotus and Apollodorus, killed by Neoptolemus. Paris, son of Priam and Hecuba in Roman mythology, the Trojan priest who judged that Io should be entrusted to the care of Zeus, after Zeus changed Io into a cow to prevent her from being carried away by a jealous Hera. According to another myth, Paris was one of the three sons of Priam by Hecuba sent with Aeneas to consult the sacred oracle of the Apollonian deity in Delphi but was drowned on the way. In both Greek and Roman mythology, the son of Prisca was the namesake of the city of Paris.

answer: Iran, also known as Persia, officially the Islamic Republic of Iran is a sovereign state in Western Asia. With 82 million inhabitants, Iran is the world's 18th most populous country. Comprising a land area of 1,648,195 km², it is the second largest country in the Middle East and the 17th largest in the world. Iran has long been a regional power and is among the world's emerging powers. Its rich and diverse history dates back to the earliest civilizations, which were documented by the ancient myths of Persus, while the country's more recent pre-Islamic and early Islamic era saw the rise of the historical Iranian empires. Iranian history has been closely tied to its geographical location, with a favorable climate and a rich supply of natural resources, including plentiful water and arable land which have both been used for farming and animal husbandry.

answer: Luxembourg[1][2][3] is a country in Western Europe, bordered by the Netherlands to the north, Germany to the east, and France to the south. It comprises two principal regions: the Oesling in the north as part of the Ardennes Massif, and the Gutland in the south. It additionally is confronted on the west by the German-administered part of the former Prussian province of Rhine Prussia and on the southwest by the French-administered part of Lorraine. Luxembourgers are natives of Luxembourg. The country has a population of about 610,000[2][4] people, from a variety of ethnic backgrounds. A representative democracy with a constitutional monarchy, Luxembourg is ruled by a constitutional grand duke.[1] A member of the European Union, Luxembourg is also a founder and current member of the eurozone.

USER:
answer: Nikola Tesla (Serbian Cyrillic: Никола Тесла; 10 July 1856 – 7 January 1943) was a Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, mechanical engineer, physicist, and futurist who is best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system. Tesla gained experience in telephony and electrical engineering before emigrating to the United States in 1884 to work for Thomas Edison in New York City. He soon struck out on his own with financial backers, setting up laboratories and companies to develop a range of electrical devices. His patented AC induction motor and transformer were licensed by George Westinghouse, who also hired Tesla as a consultant to help develop a reliable power supply for the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, Illinois. Tesla is the father of mechanical and AC motors and turbines, of high frequency alternating current, of the transistor, remote control, wireless control, and robotics, among many other accomplishments.

answer: Ilkhanate was a breakaway state of the Mongol Empire, which was ruled by the Mongol House of Hulagu in southwestern Asia and the eastern Arab world. It was founded by Hulagu Khan, son of Tolui and grandson of Genghis Khan. With the fragmentation of the Mongol Empire after 1259 it became a functionally separate khanate. At its greatest extent, the state stretched from the Caspian Sea to central Anatolia and from the Amu Darya south to the border of Iran with the Sultanate of Rum (Anatolia).

answer: Little Miss Sunshine is a 2006 American comedy-drama road movie, directed and co-written by the husband-wife team of Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris. The film made its world premiere at the Sundance Film Festival in January 2006, where the film became one of the most talked about independent films and was eventually sold to Fox Searchlight Pictures for $10.5 million. The film opened in the United States to widespread critical acclaim on July 26, 2006.

answer: Saamy is a 2003 Indian Tamil action drama film co-written and directed by Hari. Starring Vikram as the lead, it also features Trisha Keerthi Shrima Narayanan, Mahima Nambiar, Vivek, Khushboo and M. S. Bhaskar among others. It was simultaneously shot and dubbed in Telugu as Saamin and released at the same time as the Tamil version. The soundtrack featured lyrics by Vaali, and music composed by Devisriprasad. Upon the success of the film, the sequel Saamy Square began production on October 2015. The sequel was released on 14 December 2018.

answer: Leopold II of Belgium (3 April 1835 – 17 December 1909) was King of the Belgians between 1865 and 1909. Born in Brussels as the second but eldest surviving son of Leopold I and Louise of Orléans, he succeeded his father to the Belgian throne in 1865 and reigned for 44 years. He also held the title of Grand Duke of Tuscany, a title he inherited from his maternal grandfather, from 1860 to 1870. His political ambitions caused friction between the Netherlands and Belgium and led to the collapse of the Dutch–Belgian koninkrijks (or United States of Belgium).

answer: Elvis Presley (; January 8, 1935 – August 16, 1977) was an American singer, actor and songwriter. One of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century, he is often referred to as "the King of Rock and Roll", or simply, "the King". His music career began there in 1954 when he started to work with Sam Phillips, the owner of Sun Records. Accompanied by guitarist Scotty Moore and bassist Bill Black, Presley was an early popularizer of rockabilly, an uptempo, backbeat-driven fusion of country music and rhythm and blues. RCA Victor acquired his contract in a deal arranged by Colonel Tom Parker, who was to manage the singer for more than two decades. Presley's first RCA single, "Heartbreak Hotel", released in January 1956, was a number-one hit in the US. He became the leading figure of rock and roll after a series of network television appearances and chart-topping records. His energized interpretations of songs and sexually provocative performance style, combined with a singularly potent mix of influences across color lines that coincided with the dawn of the Civil Rights Movement, made him enormously popular—and controversial. In November 1956, he made his film debut in Love Me Tender.

answer: Venus is the second-closest planet to the Sun, orbiting it every 224.7 days. It has an eccentric orbit and rotates slowly, progressing from west to east. It has been called "Earth's sister planet" but was historically considered a malefic planet. It was probably once a comet that entered the inner Solar System. It is the most similar of all the Earth's neighbors, being like Earth in mass, size, and bulk composition. However, its surface is more geologically active than Earth's and it lacks a magnetic field and an asteroid belt. Its surface is in active competition with Earth, with Earth being roughly 4.5 billion years old and Venus being roughly 4.9 billion years old. It is shrouded by an opaque layer of highly reflective clouds of sulfuric acid, preventing its surface from being seen from space, except in rare instances when the planetary albedo provides sufficient reflection to reveal the planet's cloud-tops. It may have had water oceans in the past, but these may have dried up over the course of Venus's history.

USER:
answer: Cosmopolitan (magazine) is a worldwide magazine for women. Often referred to as Cosmo, its content as of 2011 includes articles on sex, relationships, health, careers, self-improvement, as well as celebrity gossip, fashion and beauty. Published by the Hearst Corporation, Cosmopolitan has 64 international editions, is printed in 35 languages, and is distributed in more than 100 countries. Cosmopolitan began as a family magazine, launched on March 16, 1886 by scholar John Jay Chapman, literary editor Mary Harmon, political advice columnist Hamilton Owens. The first issue was sold at newsstands for one cent. By 1889, when it was purchased by Schlicht & Field, it was the most successful women's magazine. By 1892, circulation had increased to 25,000, allowing the magazine to turn a profit. That same year, William Randolph Hearst began distribution of the magazine through the Cosmopolitan Book Corporation (1892–1905). By 1894, circulation increased to 75,000. At the time, it was commonly understood that printing and circulation costs were the greatest costs for any publisher, making advertising important for revenue. To increase advertising revenue, in 1897 Hearst introduced sections or "chapters" of special editorial content which could be sponsored by advertisers. These sponsored sections could be thicker than other portions of the magazine and they allowed the magazine to have a greater number of advertising pages. That same year, Hearst sold the magazine to a New York firm to concentrate on the New York Journal. In 1911, the magazine was acquired by Schlicht & Field as a result of the bankruptcy of the Cosmopolitan Book Corporation. In 1915, it was bought by William Randolph Hearst and the Hearst Corporation. The early 1900s saw the rise of the modern women's magazine in the United States.

answer: Lymphoma, often spelled "lymphoma", is a group of cancers that affect the cells of the lymph system. Several types of lymphomas in humans, as well as a few types in domestic pets, exist. The most common form of the disease in humans is called non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Hodgkin's lymphoma is also a type of lymphoma that is considered to be a separate group. Lymphoma can be of either B-cell or T-cell lineage, and the two are very different, having different morphology and different sites of origin. The great majority of cases are malignant and a rare minority are benign. As a group, lymphomas cause approximately 3% of all cancers and about 3.3% of deaths due to cancer.

answer: Archimedes of Syracuse (; Greek: Ἀρχιμήδης; c. 287 – c. 212 BC) was a Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, inventor, and astrologer. Although few details of his life are known, he is regarded as one of the leading scientists in classical antiquity. Generally considered the greatest mathematician of antiquity and one of the greatest of all time, Archimedes anticipated modern calculus and analysis by applying concepts of infinitesimals and the method of exhaustion to derive and rigorously prove a range of geometrical theorems, including the area of a circle, the surface area and volume of a sphere, and the area under the arc of a parabola.

topic: Felicity Jones, The Theory of Everything (2014 film)
answer: Felicity Jones is an English actress. Jones was educated at Woldingham School, and later trained as an actress at the Oxford School of Drama, graduating in 2006. Following her professional debut in 2006, she worked steadily in the West End and in television for the next five years, including appearances in Law and Order: UK, The Archers, Cranford and Silk (TV series). She appeared in the 2011 science fiction film Like Crazy, for which she won a Special Jury Prize at the 2011 Sundance Film Festival. The film also earned her a nomination for Best Actress in 2012 from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts. In 2014, she appeared in The Theory of Everything for which she was nominated for Golden Globe, Screen Actors Guild, BAFTA, and Academy Awards for Best Actress.

answer: The Bourne Supremacy (film) is a 2004 American-German action spy thriller film and the second installment in the Bourne film series, based on Robert Ludlum's character Jason Bourne. It was written, directed, and produced by Paul Greengrass. The previous director, Doug Liman, was going to direct, but left due to budgetary and scheduling conflicts. It was filmed in Berlin, Paris, Tangier, and Odessa, Ukraine, with Berlin standing in for multiple locations in Italy and Russia. After Damon expressed a desire to not return, Greengrass wrote a screenplay centering on Bourne's amnesia and struggle to find out his true identity, while establishing the character's relationships with those in the CIA. The Bourne Supremacy was highly acclaimed as a whole, with critics particularly praising its performances, action scenes, soundtrack and direction. It grossed $288 million worldwide, and has been listed among the best spy movies of all time.

answer: Caspian Sea (Russian: Каспи́йское мо́ре, Kaspiyskoye More; Persian: دریای خزر‎, Darayā-ye Khazreh; Azerbaijani: Xəzər dənizi; Kazakh: Каспий теңізі, Qaspıy teňizi; Turkish: Kafa Körfezi; Armenian: Ջորժհեշ լռնան) is the largest enclosed inland body of water on Earth by area, variously classed as the world's largest lake or a full-fledged sea. It is an endorheic basin (a basin without outflows) located between Europe and Asia. It is bounded by Kazakhstan to the northeast, Russia to the northwest, Azerbaijan to the west, Iran to the south, and Turkmenistan to the southeast.

After writing in different forms throughout the 1880s, he became one of London's most popular playwrights in the early 1890s. He became known for his involvement in the rising philosophy of aestheticism, led by two of his tutors, Walter Pater and John Ruskin.

All of the victims were buried in the crawl space within the house. Some of Gacy's earlier murders were exhumed along with other bodies found beneath the floorboards soon after Gacy's arrest by authorities in December 1978. He became a suspect in the unsolved murders of further victims that occurred nationwide.Gacy was convicted of ten counts of murder and later executed by lethal injection May 10, 1994, at Stateville Correctional Center in Crest Hill, Illinois.

answer: Reuters Limited or simply Reuters is a British multinational media company headquartered in London, UK. It has traditionally specialised in financial data. USER:
answer: Dayton Agreement or Dayton Accords is the name for the peace agreement reached at the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio on November 21, 1995, signed in Paris on December 14, 1995, formally ending the war in the former state of Yugoslavia. The agreement was brokered by the G6 Foreign ministers, i.e. the five permanent members of the UN Security Council plus Germany, with the United States, the European Union and Russia playing leading roles. The Dayton Accords put and end to the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and gave birth to a statelet known as the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The agreement created a complex system of governance for former Yugoslavia's provinces, created joint security forces (primarily consisting of the Army of RS and JNA), established rules for the division of territory to the two sides, and the power to be shared among the three major ethnic groups. However, the military aspects of the agreement did not last long, as a general conflict between former members of the Army of Yugoslav Federation and Army of the Republic of Serbia continued into the creation of the Army of the Bosnian Federation (Vojska Federacije Bosne i Hercegovine).

answer: Pacific Rim (film) is a 2013 American science fiction monster film directed by Guillermo del Toro and starring Charlie Hunnam, Idris Elba, Rinko Kikuchi, Charlie Day, Burn Gorman, Robert Kazinsky, Max Martini, and Ron Perlman. The screenplay was written by Travis Beacham and del Toro from a story by Beacham. The film is set in the future, when Earth is at war with the Kaiju, colossal sea monsters which have emerged from an interdimensional gateway on the bottom of the Pacific Ocean. To combat the monsters, humanity unites to create the “Jaegers”, extraordinary machines which are controlled by two pilots whose minds are locked in a neural bridge. Focusing on the war's later stages, the story follows Raleigh Becket, a washed-up Jaeger pilot called out of retirement and teamed with rookie pilot Mako Mori (Kikuchi) as part of a last-ditch effort to defeat the Kaiju.

answer: Blue Velvet (film) Blue Velvet is a 1986 American neo-noir mystery film written and directed by David Lynch and stars Kyle MacLachlan, Isabella Rossellini, Dennis Hopper and Laura Dern. Since 2007, it has been in the Library of Congress National Film Registry. The soundtrack was composed and performed by renowned American singer-songwriter and composer, Bobby Vinton, at the request of the film's director. However, the tracks were unused. The film concerns college student Jeffrey Beaumont (Kyle MacLachlan) who returns home to his small North Carolina hometown following his father's stroke and the discovery of a severed human ear. Jeffrey is initially drawn into a web of mystery that leads him to detective John Williams (George Dickerson), whom he befriends and later partners up with to solve the puzzle alongside Williams' daughter Sandy Williams (Laura Dern).

answer: Rain Man is a 1988 American comedy-drama film written by Barry Morrow and Ronald Bass, directed by Barry Levinson and starring Dustin Hoffman and Tom Cruise. Babbitt is left with $3 million in a trust fund for Raymond's care and treats it as his compensation from the death of his father, whom he disliked. Raymond and Charlie are forced to embark on a road trip to Los Angeles, where Raymond hopes to have his name entered into the National Rain Man's Association, a savant-identified service. Raymond asks a woman (Valeria Golino) stranded on the side of the road to join them.

topic: Rick and Morty, Dan Harmon, Justin Roiland
answer: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated science fiction television series created by Justin Roiland and Dan Harmon for Cartoon Network's late-night programming block Adult Swim. The series follows the misadventures of alcoholic scientist Rick Sanchez and his fretful but easily influenced grandson Morty Smith, who split their time between domestic family life and interdimensional adventures. Roiland provides the voices for both Rick and Morty, as well as Jessica and Tammy without bodily movement. The series has received critical acclaim for its dark humor and surrealist comedy, as well as its frequent breaks from linear storytelling. It has received multiple writing nominations from the Primetime Emmy Awards and Annie Awards, as well as a 2017 Peabody Award.

answer: Hypothyroidism is a disorder in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough of certain important hormones. Hypothyroidism is most commonly due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is more common in women than men. The average age of onset is about 45 years. Other causes include thyroiditis from medications, radiation treated neck or thyroid surgery, thyroplasty or thyroidectomy, congenital or acquired hypothyroidism, and defects in iodine metabolism.

USER:
answer: Ecuador, officially the Republic of Ecuador, is a country in northwestern South America, bordered by Colombia on the north, Peru on the east and south, and the Pacific Ocean on the west. Ecuador also includes the Galápagos Islands in the Pacific, about 1,000 kilometres west of the mainland. What is now Ecuador was home to a variety of Amerindian groups that were incorporated into the Inca Empire during the fifteenth century. The territories of the Sierra and what is now the coastal region were conquered by the Spanish in the sixteenth century, resulting in a colonial deposition that lasted almost three centuries. As a result of years of revolutions and civil wars, Ecuador is one of the few countries in Latin America that did not break up, remaining instead a weak republic until the Ecuadorian War of Independence, which took place between 1809 and 1822, and were led by the Ecuadorian born Venezuelan-born revolutionary Antonio José de Sucre. Ecuador is a middle income and democratic developing country. Its capital city is Quito, while its largest city is Guayaquil. Ecuador is a developed country with an mixed market and agrarian economy that is highly dependent on commodities, namely petroleum, which has accounted for 35% of the country's export revenues in recent years, it also produces chemicals, textiles, and basic metals. Its primary exports include petroleum, bananas, cut flowers, shrimp, cacao beans, gold, and coffee beans.

topic: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song)
answer: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song) is a song by American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars from his debut studio album Doo-Wops & Hooligans (2010). Written by Mars, Philip Lawrence, Ari Levine, and Khalil Walton, its lyrical content talks about a man who wants to compliment a woman for who she is. The song was released as the lead single from Doo-Wops & Hooligans on July 19, 2010. It was a commercial success, reaching the top ten in several countries: the United Kingdom, Australia, France, and the Netherlands. In the United States it became Mars' first number-one single. The song is one of the best-selling singles of all time, having sold over 10 million copies.

USER:
answer: Vedanta ( /vɛˈdæntə/), from Latin vedānta meaning "the end of knowledge", is the stage of cognition characterized by identification with the Self or Ātman in Hindu philosophy. This identity is expressed by the "neti neti" (no, no) affirmations or the "netatmyavada" (no soul doctrine) attributed to the sage Yajnavalkya. In contrast to the ātman or "true self", the ego is characterized as "false" or illusory, and is transcended by the realization of one's intrinsic unity with Brahman in Advaita Vedanta philosophy. This term usually refers to the monistic theistic interpretation of the Vedas and is associated with Dvaita Vedanta, while Dualistic Vedanta theism is called "Vaishnavism" or "Shauvism".

answer: Coldplay is a British rock band formed in 1996 by lead vocalist and keyboardist Chris Martin and lead guitarist Jonny Buckland at University College London (UCL). Its economic centre is Porto-Novo, the formal capital of the country, which is home to the country's MET. Cotonou, the largest city and economic centre of Benin, is the seat of government.

USER:
answer: Malala Yousafzai (/məˈlɑːlə ˈyousəfzəɪ, -ʒɑːli, -ʒæli/; Urdu/Pashto:ملالہ یوسفزئی; Pashto pronunciation: [malɑːlɑ jusofzɑi]; born 12 July 1997) is a Pakistani activist for female education and the youngest Nobel Prize laureate. She is known mainly for human rights advocacy for the education of women and children in her native Swat Valley in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, northwest Pakistan, where the local Taliban had at times banned girls from attending school. Her advocacy has grown into an international movement.

answer: Odyssey is a legendary epic poem written by Homer and recited orally before it was written down as well as a sequel to the Iliad. The epic starts after the end of the ten year Trojan War that is described in the Iliad and Odysseus has still not returned home. USER:
answer: Haifa (Arabic: ‎حيفا‎, also referred to as Haiffa or Haieffa) is the largest seaport of northern Israel. The city of Haifa is located at the foot of Mount Carmel. It extends to the territorial municipal waters of one of the world's leading technological centers in electronics and computer science. The Haifa Municipality offers a vast array of municipal services and provides social welfare programmes for the general public. Since the 2000s, the municipality has promoted tourism and encouraged the establishment of major national and international cultural attractions that add further cultural and touristic venues to the city. In 2012, the city was named by the BBC as the 7th most liveable city in the Arab Region, 2nd most liveable city in Israel and 60th overall.

answer: Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 film and the second part of the Back to the Future trilogy. answer: Taraji P. Henson is an American actress and singer. The screenplay by Kieran Fitzgerald and Tommy Lee Jones is based on the novel of the same name by Glendon Swarthout. The plot concerns a claim jumper (Swank) who helps three women to escape from their remote Midwestern frontier town against their wishes, and in her journey back home, she hires a claim jumper (Jones) to accompany her. The film premiered in competition at the 71st Venice International Film Festival on September 5, 2014. It was released in the United States on November 20, 2014, received critical praise for its writing, direction, and cinematography, and garnered four Oscar nominations, including a Best Supporting Actress nomination for Swank.

USER:
answer: Rock music is a genre of popular music that originated as "rock and roll" in the United States in the early 1950s, and developed into a range of different styles in the 1960s and later, particularly in the United Kingdom and in the United States. It has its roots in 1940s' and 1950s' rock and roll, a style which drew heavily on the genres of blues, rhythm and blues, and country and western, and moved into a more youth-orientated pop-style music in the second half of the 1950s. Rock music has also drawn strongly on a number of other genres such as electric blues and folk music, and incorporated influences from jazz, classical and other musical traditions, which have collectively been termed rock music. Although rock has had its roots in the United States at first, it was adopted and blended into local cultures across the globe, and in the 1970s, rock became infused with heavy metal and punk.

answer: Agatha Christie was a British crime writer of novels, short stories, and plays published under her name. She also wrote romances as Mary Westmacott, but she is best remembered for her 80 detective novels. She is considered one of the greatest writers of mysteries. According to the Guinness World Records, Christie's works come third in the list of best-selling books, behind only Shakespeare and the Bible. She is the only British crime writer to have been given officer rank in the French military: in 1919 she was made a Commander of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres for her contribution to the arts of France. She has been called the "Queen of Crime", a title bestowed by the Academy of Crime as a lifetime achievement award for someone who has contributed to the field of crime literature. Her first novel, the Belgian expatriate tale The Mysterious Affair at Styles, was published in 1920. Two years later, The Blue Book magazine published a list of the best 100 books since 1920, with The Murder of Roger Ackroyd placed at no. 39 and And Then There Were None at no. 77 on the list, marking the enduring appeal of Agatha Christie's novels. She is credited with making detective and crime stories accessible to a wide audience, particularly with books such as The Mysterious Affair at Styles. She was successful because, unlike Edgar Allan Poe, she did not create stories about evil geniuses – instead she used "regular" people to solve the crimes. answer: Boot Monument (Dutch: Bootsbeeld) is a monument depicting the statue of a Dutch soldier, in Amsterdam. The Boot Monument stands at Dam Square, close to the National Monument and the New Westerkerk, in front of a wall with names of Dutch war casualties from World War II. It was donated by the United States of America as a form of appreciation for Dutch support in World War II, and was unveiled on 7 May 1949 by Secretary of State Dean Acheson.

answer: Taraji P. Henson (born September 11, 1970) is an American actress, singer and author. answer: Led Zeppelin II is the second studio album by the English rock band Led Zeppelin, released on 22 October 1969 in the United Kingdom by Atlantic Records and on 24 November by Atlantic subsidiary Swan Song in North America. USER:
answer: Vietnam War (Chuẩn quốc dân chреng Riềng Biệt Nam; or 戰爭越南 Cheng zheng Yuè Nán), also known as the Second Indochina War and the Vietnam Conflict, was a cold war-era military conflict that occurred in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia from 1 November 1955 to the fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975. This war followed the First Indochina War (1946–54) and was fought between North Vietnam—supported by the Soviet Union, China, and other communist allies—and the government of South Vietnam—supported by the United States, Philippines, Australia, Thailand and other anti-communist allies. The war is considered a Cold War-eraproxy war by some US perspectives, and some of the larger operations in it were, at times, carried out concurrently with the Laotian Civil War and the Cambodian Civil War; all three were largely fought by proxy forces in the region, with the US and Soviet Union supplying their respective proxies with weapons, training and intelligence support. Most of the fighting during the Vietnam War occurred in South Vietnam, but fighting also occurred in the north, Laos, and Cambodia, and from 1961–1970, small-scale battles occurred in Vietnam's Central Highlands. The primary military entities were the North Vietnamese Army and the People's Army of Vietnamfor the Communist side, and the Army of the Republic of Vietnam (ARVN) and, beginning in 1965, the Republic of Korea Armed Forces (KorUS) and the US Armed Forces for the South Vietnamese side. The Viet Cong (also known as the National Liberation Front, or NLF), a South Vietnamese communist common front aided by the North, also participated in the war.

answer: Russia (Russian: Rossiya), officially the Russian Federation (Russian: Российская Федерация, tr. Rossiyskaya Federatsiya), is a country in Eurasia. According to the most researched version of the chronology of the ancient history of the Russian state, the foundations of Russian culture and civilization date back to the year 862 - that is, over 1000 years before Europe began to emerge from the twilight of the Dark Ages. At the end of 12th century, Russian princes gradually converted to Orthodox Christianity and gradually moved to a strong, centralized state. The Grand Duchy of Moscow, one of the major centers of Russian principalities, became the centre of the struggle with the Mongols for the reunification of the Russian lands. There were 203 ethnic groups in Russia in 1989 (according to Soviet census of 1989), and more recent ethnic estimate was 160 ethnic groups in 2002. Russians constitute the largest ethnic group in Russia (81%); Apart from the ethnic Russians, the population of Russia consists of more than 180 other ethnic groups. On behalf of Russia, the Federation Council adopts federal constitutional laws, federal laws and acts concerning foreign policy, and also adopts the decisions made by the Council of Ministers on behalf of the Russian government on the issues within the legislative jurisdiction of the federal government, issues of federal jurisdiction which are determined by a federal law or an international agreement that is part of federal law.

It is an island of the western Pacific Ocean and located off the southeastern coast of mainland China across the Taiwan Strait. It encompasses Taiwan Province and Lienchiang (Matsu) County. answer: J. J. Cale (November 5, 1938 – July 26, 2013) was an American singer-songwriter, whose songs have been covered successfully by many musicians, including Eric Clapton, Widespread Panic, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Johnny Cash, Santana, Nirvana, Lucinda Williams, Jerry Garcia, Captain Beefheart, Neil Young, Dire Straits, Willie Nelson, Ryan Adams, and others. Both of Cale's parents were musicians and the family moved frequently throughout Oklahoma. answer: Anthony Meindl is an American actor, author, and acting coach. He was born in the town of Chester, New York and is of Italian ancestry. He grew up outside of Rochester, New York in a poor, broken home. After his mother’s abusive boyfriend forced them to runaway from home with just a change of clothes when he was 6 years old, Anthony worked odd jobs to support himself and his alcoholic mother. In his mid-teenage years, after discovering acting in a playwriting class in high school, he got a scholarship to study acting at the American Music and Dramatic Academy (AMDA) in Los Angeles, which is where he received most of his training at the time. His dreams of being an actor drove him to move to NYC at 18 where he lived in Brooklyn Heights and slept in parks because he couldn’t afford an apartment, despite working three jobs. During that time, he worked as a waiter, delivered junk mail, and washed cars to support himself. Anthony’s love of acting drove him to fight for his dream and despite many obstacles and poverty, it’s his love of the craft and his passion for teaching that’s given him the opportunity to become one of the most in-demand coaches in Hollywood.

The set consists of: A Lovebox, a compilation with tracks covering the period 1960 through 2003 from across many genres, a mix of new, old and classic recordings. In the liner notes, The Lovebox is billed as "Music from the Age of Reason until the Millennium, from Bing Crosby to Bob Dylan, and Patsy Cline to Pulp. answer: Horrible Bosses is a 2011 American black comedy film directed by Seth Gordon, written by Michael Markowitz, John Francis Daley and Jonathan Goldstein, based on a story by Markowitz. It stars Jason Bateman, Charlie Day, Jason Sudeikis, Jennifer Aniston, Colin Farrell, Kevin Spacey and Jamie Foxx. A sequel, Horrible Bosses 2 was released on November 26, 2014, and a follow-up, Horrible Bosses 3, has been announced. The movie also has a direct-to-TV prequel titled Horrible Bosses: The Second Coming filmed on March 20–April 2, 2020.
